title: How to Wash Old Lace

steps.headline: Fill a bowl or container of suitable size with warm, soapy water.
steps.description: Use a gentle soap, such as liquid castile.

steps.headline: Assess the condition of the lace.
steps.description: If it isn't unravelling, weakened or coming apart, wash by dipping it into the soapy water. Very gently squeeze and knead the lace.

steps.headline: Remove and rinse in warm water.
Stiffen if needed.
Dry the lace.
steps.description: Simply roll it in a clean towel until it has almost dried.

steps.headline: Place a towel over the wrong side of the almost dry lace on the ironing board.
steps.description: Iron over the lace under the towel. This will both press the lace and cause the pattern to stand out.

text:
Fill a bowl or container of suitable size with warm, soapy water. Use a gentle soap, such as liquid castile. Assess the condition of the lace. If it isn't unravelling, weakened or coming apart, wash by dipping it into the soapy water. Very gently squeeze and knead the lace. Remove and rinse in warm water. Stiffen if needed. If you'd like to stiffen the old lace again, use gum arabic. Dissolve 125g of gum arabic in ⁄2 liter (0.1 US gal) of hot water. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Strain the mixture. Pour into a bottle. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Add 1 to 3 tablespoons of this mix at room temperature to every ⁄2 liter (0.1 US gal) of warm water at the rinse cycle stage when washing the lace. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Wash-Old-Lace-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Dry the lace. Simply roll it in a clean towel until it has almost dried. Place a towel over the wrong side of the almost dry lace on the ironing board. Iron over the lace under the towel. This will both press the lace and cause the pattern to stand out.
